author: gary0128
content:
Is it possible for a node operator who is solo-staking to prove that that is the case to an outsider? Claude.ai makes the following recommendations, but I'd be interested in the opinions of Ethereum insiders, who I trust do not share Claude's susceptibility to hallucinations and who know more than Claude:



Multi-Signature Challenge-Response

The validator must prove control of BOTH:
a) The validator signing key (using BLS signature)
b) The withdrawal address (using ECDSA signature)
Both signatures should be over the same challenge message containing a recent timestamp


On-Chain Verification

The withdrawal credentials must point to an EOA (Externally Owned Account), not a contract
The withdrawal address must not be associated with any known staking pools or liquid staking derivatives
Can verify the validator's deposit history through the deposit contract


Additional Proofs

Provide proof of the deposit transaction coming from a personal wallet
Show historical validator performance data to demonstrate independent operation
Sign additional statements confirming solo operation and no delegation


Time-Lock Component

Implement a challenge period where the proof remains valid only if:

The withdrawal credentials don't change
No liquid staking derivatives are minted against the validator
The validator continues normal attestation behavior
